node.title: The COVID-19 pandemic positives for Australians living with disabilities
node.description: From the blind photographer observing details, to living solo for the first time, or discovering the power of roller skating — the pandemic for these Australians living with disabilities has been a chance to find joy, independence and new passions.

node.title: The COVID-19 tests expected to form a 'line of defence' when WA opens its doors to the world
node.description: When Western Australia finally opens its doors to the rest of the world – potentially letting in the Omicron variant of COVID-19 – rapid antigen self-tests could form an important line of defence to prevent  outbreaks in high-risk settings.

node.title: Susan Neill-Fraser will find out tomorrow if she can walk free from prison — here's what her appeal is about
node.description: Neill-Fraser has been fighting to clear her name ever since she was charged with murdering her partner, Bob Chappell, in 2009. A decision in her latest appeal will be handed down almost nine months after her lawyers argued there has been a miscarriage of justice.

node.title: There's backlash to China's LGBTQI+ movement — but it's not lead by religious groups
node.description: Queer communities in China are increasingly seen as a political threat to state stability, writes Jinghua Qian.

node.title: How Nas Campanella's TV debut helped her think about motherhood
node.description: Years ago Nas Campanella played a pregnant woman on prime time TV. The experience made her feel conflicted — but it also helped her think about motherhood.

node.title: Slip south of Gisborne destroys wāhi tapu and hopes of railway's reinstatement
node.description: A huge slip along the mothballed rail line between Gisborne and Wairoa has destroyed sacred Māori whenua and dashed hopes of the railway being reinstated.

node.title: Listen to Stephen Sondheim’s 20 Essential Songs
node.description: The lyricist and composer, who died on Friday, wrote dozens of piercing tunes for Broadway. Here is a selection of them, as lean as a Sondheim couplet.

node.title: Housing affordability is a national crisis, but for one group of young people it can be life changing
node.description: The housing affordability crisis is being felt acutely by young people with a disability, partly because the hidden costs of having a disability can make it much more difficult to save a deposit and pay off a mortgage.

node.title: Father manufactures medicine for sick son in China after COVID-19 limits treatment
node.description: A desperate father is manufacturing medicine for his sick son after he was unable to get treatment in his country due to COVID-19.

node.title: Ashlie used to help feed the homeless, now at 64 she's homeless herself
node.description: After falling into an unexpected cycle of disadvantage, Ashlie Stevenson is one of hundreds of thousands of Australians languishing on waiting lists for public housing.

node.title: The billionaire, the socialite and the 'little black book': Ghislaine Maxwell's trial finally begins
node.description: Sixteen months after FBI agents swooped in on her remote hideaway to arrest Ghislaine Maxwell on sex abuse charges, the trial of the British socialite is beginning in New York. Here's what you need to know.

node.title: A death tax by stealth? Your super savings could be subject to a hefty tax when you die
node.description: It's not called a 'death tax', but millions of Australians' retirement savings may be taxable upon death, writes Nassim Khadem.

node.title: 'We live history' says director keen to make Waikato Museum 'hum'
node.description: In 100 years' time people will study our response to the Covid-19 pandemic - just as we look back at the 1918 flu pandemic, a museum director says. Audio

node.title: South Africa, whose scientists detected Omicron, is an outlier on the least vaccinated continent.
node.description: The country has one of Africa’s better vaccination rates: Just under one quarter of its population has been fully vaccinated.

node.title: 1/6 Panel Decision on Criminal Contempt Charges for Mark Meadows Likely This Week: Schiff
node.description: "We are moving with alacrity with anyone who obstructs the committee, and that was certainly the case with Mr. Bannon, and it will be the case with Mr. Meadows," said California Democratic Congressman Adam Schiff.

node.title: Cinemas opening in the traffic light system: What to expect
node.description: Auckland cinemas are preparing to open after being closed for more than 100 days but going to the movies will be a different experience under the traffic light system. Here is what you can expect. Video

node.title: Fox News Host Confronts GOP Senator for Opposing Debt Limit Hike, Notes Benefits in His State
node.description: "This is to pay for things already authorized," Fox News host Trace Gallagher explained to Wyoming Senator John Barrasso.

node.title: Amazon's consumer chief says hiring remains a "challenge"
node.description: Dave Clark, the CEO of Amazon Worldwide Consumer, says the company is hiring thousands of workers by offering incentives and higher wages.

node.title: Michael Cohen Says Trump Running 'Greatest Grift in U.S. History' With 'Big Lie,' Won't Run
node.description: "If he loses, which he will, in 2024, what happens to the Big Lie? The Big Lie disappears," Donald Trump's ex-lawyer said.

node.title: Indian bowlers trouble Blackcaps on day three
node.description: Left-arm spinner Axar Patel claimed figures of 5-62 to help India grab a handy 49-run first-innings lead in the opening test against New Zealand.

node.title: NZ well placed to contain new Omicron Covid variant - expert
node.description: An infectious diseases expert believes the country is well placed to detect and respond to any cases of the Omicron Covid-19 variant. Audio

node.title: 'Disappointing' National Party needs 'new vision'  - Former PM
node.description: Former Prime Minister Jim Bolger has weighed in on the National Party's leadership race, saying that the party he once led needs to have a serious think about where it wants to go.

node.title: Gottlieb says Omicron variant "almost definitely" already in U.S.
node.description: "We're in a much better place now than we were a year ago" with detecting cases of the Omicron variant, Gottlieb said.

node.title: Transcript: Amazon's Dave Clark on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Amazon CEO, Worldwide Consumer, Dave Clark that aired Sunday, November 28, 2021, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: ‘Long Live “Wokeness”!’ Or Is It Doomed?
node.description: On John McWhorter’s call for a new term and Bret Stephens’s assertion that wokeness will fail. Also: Maternal health; American exceptionalism; Facebook.

node.title: Sylvia Weinstock, the ‘da Vinci of Wedding Cakes,’ Dies at 91
node.description: She produced floral-draped architectural works in the shape of rose-studded topiaries, baskets of speckled lilies and bouquets of anemones.

node.title: Omicron Found in 13 Air Passengers as Fauci Warns Variant May Elude Vaccines
node.description: Officials in the Netherlands found that a total of 61 travelers who arrived on flights from South Africa on Friday had tested positive for COVID-19.

node.title: We Got a Head Start on Omicron, So Let’s Not Blow It
node.description: South Africa gave the world an early warning. Decisive action on containment and surveillance could help us control it.

node.title: You Can Make Any Day the Best Day of the Year
node.description: A thought experiment for finding more happiness in the everyday.

node.title: Why the Feminist Movement Needs Pro-Life People
node.description: We must form a broad and diverse coalition to advocate for women.

node.title: As concerts return to South Korea, fans are told not to sing along.
node.description: South Koreans including K-pop fans will not be able to shout, chant or sing at performances with 500 or more attendees, according to government rules.

node.title: In a Nonbinary Pronoun, France Sees a U.S. Attack on the Republic
node.description: When a French dictionary included the gender-nonspecific “iel” for the first time, a virulent reaction erupted over “wokisme” exported from American universities.

node.title: Moderna CMO Says Omicron Variant May Elude Current Vaccines
node.description: A reformulated vaccine could be available early in 2022, Moderna's chief medical officer Paul Burton said.

node.title: GOP Gov. Hutchinson Says Kevin McCarthy Should Be 'Publicly Condemning' Gosar, Boebert
node.description: "It has to be called out," the Republican Arkansas governor said.

node.title: Rugby: Justice for the Pacific Islands? There is a bit more to it
node.description: Comment: The final whistle has blown on the Southern Hemisphere season, but perhaps the most significant victory was when World Rugby opened up their eligibility rules, Jamie Wall writes.

node.title: Trump Jr. Says Americans Acting 'Like Sheep' by Not Rioting Against Vaccine Mandates
node.description: "He [Biden] has overperformed in only one thing, which is I thought it would take him much longer to destroy America. He's managed to do it in 10 months," said Donald Trump Jr.

node.title: Pat Benatar and Neil Giraldo's rock & roll love story
node.description: One of rock's most enduring couples talks about their 40-year-marriage and creative partnership, which has sold 36 million albums, recorded 15 Top 40 hits, and won four consecutive Grammys, and is still going strong.

node.title: Lessons from Stephen Sondheim, the teacher
node.description: Correspondent (and pianist) David Pogue remembers the advice given him by the musical theater giant.

node.title: John Wilson on how to become a TV sensation
node.description: The New York filmmaker, host of HBO's critically-acclaimed series, "How To with John Wilson," talks about creating his pseudo instructional videos that he says are like nature documentaries about contemporary life.

node.title: Fauci warns of "potential" for new COVID-19 wave
node.description: Fauci's comments come as the world scrambles to contain the new Omicron variant discovered in South Africa.

node.title: When Is a Horror Movie Not a Horror Movie?
node.description: When “The Humans” and other new dramas use jump scares and other genre staples, it’s a fair question to ask.

node.title: First, I Cried. Then, I Rode My Bike.
node.description: Pedal, pedal, pedal, glide.

node.title: VIDEO: Astonished Cops Find $3 Million in Random Traffic Stop
node.description: Tightly packed wads of Australian bills were crammed into two duffel bags in a car's trunk.

node.title: Former GOP Congresswoman Urges Voters to Oust Boebert, Greene: 'Take Out the Trash'
node.description: "She needs to apologize to the Republican Party and a lot of other people. It goes way beyond that," Barbara Comstock said of the Colorado lawmaker.

node.title: Sharon Gless: In conversation
node.description: In her new memoir, "Apparently There Were Complaints," the Emmy-winning star of the classic cop series "Cagney & Lacey" examines some of her life's highs – and some terrifying lows.

node.title: GoFundMe for Waukesha Parade's Youngest Victim Raises Nearly $450K a Week After Tragedy
node.description: Donations for the victims of the attack on the Waukesha Christmas Parade last week have poured in from across the country, now totaling over $2 million.

node.title: The oldest trees on Earth
node.description: The gnarled bristlecone pines that have taken root high atop the remote, rocky slopes of California's White Mountains are the longest-lived individual trees on the planet – and they have secrets to share.

node.title: How Much Does Your Team’s Manager Matter?
node.description: One set of researchers estimated a manager is responsible for only 8 percent of a team’s results. But 8 percent, when you think about it, is a lot.

node.title: Stephen Sondheim in conversation with Patti LuPone
node.description: In 2020 the Tony-winning actress (now starring in the new Broadway revival of "Company") spoke with the musical theater giant for "CBS Sunday Morning" to discuss his craft, his favorite character, and his college acting career.

node.title: Remembering Stephen Sondheim, a musical theater giant
node.description: Correspondent Mo Rocca offers an appreciation of the career of the legendary composer and lyricist who forced the American musical to grow up, and who took audiences to places they'd never been before.

node.title: Do Sports Still Need China?
node.description: Global outrage, broken contracts and shifting politics could change the calculus for leagues and teams that once raced to do business in China.

node.title: Britain’s health secretary defends decision not to impose tougher Covid restrictions.
node.description: The government stopped short of urging people to work from home or extending vaccine passports in England after two cases of the Omicron variant were detected.

node.title: A Wine Rack on Rails? U.K. Businesses Seek Solutions to Shortages.
node.description: Two months after concerns about gas and food stocks caused ripples of anxiety, Britain continues to face problems in its supply chain. Distributors and retailers are looking for creative fixes.

node.title: Cache of Thousands of Ancient Roman Silver Coins Found in River
node.description: A huge find of 5,600 coins weighing 33 pounds was discovered after a waterway burst its banks.

node.title: Prince Andrew's Accuser Hoping to See 'Justice Done' at Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
node.description: Prosecutors allege Maxwell, 59, groomed girls as young as 14 to have sex with Jeffrey Epstein.

node.title: Hopes and concerns over a new Alzheimer's drug
node.description: The FDA's recent approval is potentially good news for the 6 million Americans who suffer from Alzheimer's disease. But the approval process has stirred controversy.

node.title: Poll: Lifestyle main factor in determining longevity, Americans say
node.description: But most would not want to live forever if they could.

node.title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
node.description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.

node.title: Netherlands confirms 13 Omicron cases as new COVID variant continues to spread
node.description: Dutch authorities say investigations will continue after the new variant was detected in 13 out of 61 travellers who tested positive for COVID-19 on flights from South Africa.

node.title: A soccer game in Portugal is abandoned after Covid reduces one team to 9 players.
node.description: Players from the Belenenses team criticized sporting officials for demanding the match go on, saying soccer had “lost its heart.”

node.title: Book excerpt: "The Sentence" by Louise Erdrich
node.description: The author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel "The Night Watchman" returns with a magical comedy about a bookstore, a convicted body snatcher, and a ghost.

node.title: Book excerpt: "On Animals" by Susan Orlean
node.description: This collection of The New Yorker magazine writer's essays evokes her lifelong fascination with all creatures great and small.

node.title: Book excerpt: "The Lyrics" by Paul McCartney
node.description: The Beatle's memoir contains stories of his life, inspiration, and the music that changed the world, set against the lyrics of 154 of his most important songs.

node.title: The Book Report: Recommendations from Washington Post critic Ron Charles (November 28)
node.description: Suggested fall fiction and non-fiction titles, on topics ranging from animals to Beatles!

node.title: Book excerpt: "The Island of Missing Trees" by Elif Shafak
node.description: The Turkish-British writer-activist prevents a hauntingly beautiful novel involving a pair of young lovers – one Turkish, one Greek – who are separated by a military invasion.

node.title: More countries restrict travel from southern Africa.
node.description: Australia, Canada and Thailand are among the latest countries to restrict travelers from the region over concerns about the Omicron variant.

node.title: Transcript: Dr. Anthony Fauci on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Dr. Anthony Fauci, chief medical adviser to President Biden, airing on Sunday, November 28, 2021, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: The W.H.O. skips forward two Greek letters, avoiding a Xi variant.
node.description: Under the World Health Organization’s system, the Omicron variant might have been called Nu or Xi, but only at the risk of ambiguity or diplomatic awkwardness.

node.title: Fox Hosts Suggest COVID Variants Are Being Made up by Democrats
node.description: Amid growing alarm about the Omicron variant, the hosts of Fox & Friends claimed new variants are being used to help Democrats.

node.title: For Ku Stevens, Running Is a ‘Profound Act’
node.description: This fall, Ku Stevens became the fastest cross-country runner in all of Nevada. But he would be running even if he wasn’t winning.

node.title: Jim Acosta Slams Kevin McCarthy for Not Standing up to GOP 'Freak Show Caucus'
node.description: "In the freak show caucus, loyalty only flows in one direction… which means more hatred, more bigotry, more glorification of violence, and more appeasement," Acosta said.

node.title: The Storyteller of Design Miami
node.description: Wava Carpenter was the fair’s first employee 15 years ago, and now she’s overseeing the content of the December edition with a theme of “Human Kind.”

node.title: A Curator Makes Room for Big Ideas and Big Art
node.description: The Mexico City curator Magalí Arriola will again assemble Meridians at Art Basel Miami Beach, a diverting lineup of hard-to-fit pieces.

node.title: In Opposite Styles, 2 African Artists Capture the Same Spirit
node.description: Marcellina Akpojotor, of Nigeria, and Sungi Mlengeya, of Tanzania, explore female empowerment and the roles of women in African society.

node.title: If You Linger in the Palm Beach Area and Boca Raton
node.description: They are packed with restaurants, stunning hotels and spectacular views.

node.title: Florida Museums Highlight Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and Machu Picchu
node.description: Museums in West Palm Beach and Boca Raton present exhibitions of the Mexican artists and of Peruvian ceramics and gold and silver ornaments.

node.title: An Artist Once Reborn Is Now Rediscovered
node.description: Maryan, who reinvented himself after surviving Nazi death camps, comes into contemporary focus in a retrospective in North Miami.

node.title: Translating Culture Through the Faces of Qatar
node.description: The artist Mubarak al-Malik is bringing a signature object — the traditional batoola face covering — to Miami in a mural that he hopes will show off his homeland.

node.title: For 2 Bogotá Galleries, Art Basel Means Business
node.description: With a limited market in Colombia, Casas Riegner and Instituto de Visión depend on art fairs to survive and to support the careers of their artists.

node.title: An Art Fair Meets a Pent-Up Demand
node.description: This year’s edition of Art Basel Miami Beach brings collectors back while welcoming a more diverse group of gallery owners.

node.title: Weaving the Threads of Applied and Contemporary Art
node.description: Works created with or inspired by textiles and crafting are being showcased at Art Basel Miami Beach and at satellite fairs.

node.title: Local News Outlets Could Reap $1.7 Billion in Build Back Better Aid
node.description: A small paper like The Storm Lake Times in Iowa would receive a big tax credit. So would Gannett, the nation’s largest news publisher.

node.title: Years of Delays, Billions in Overruns: The Dismal History of Big Infrastructure
node.description: The nation’s most ambitious engineering projects are mired in postponements and skyrocketing costs. Delivering $1.2 trillion in new infrastructure will be tough.

node.title: What’s at Stake in the Honduran Presidential Election?
node.description: Hondurans head to the polls on Sunday, but widespread political violence during the campaign and questionable results from 2017 are looming large.

node.title: ‘You’re Not Helpless’: For London Women, Learning to Fight Builds Confidence
node.description: After a year marked by isolation, loneliness and violence in the city, many self-defense and martial arts gyms say they are seeing more interest from women.

node.title: Intelligence Analysts 'Didn't Understand Donald Trump, How Far He Would Go'
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Powerball Results, Numbers for 11/27/21: Did Anyone Win the $243M Jackpot?
node.description: The Powerball numbers on Saturday were 8, 32, 55, 64 and 66. The Powerball was 10 and the Power Play was 2X.

node.title: Woman in custody after fire at Cairns Covid-19 quarantine hotel
node.description: A 31-year-old woman is in police custody after a fire broke out at a Cairns quarantine hotel early on Sunday morning, forcing the evacuation of more than 160 people.

node.title: Uber Survived the Spying Scandal. Their Careers Didn’t.
node.description: A former co-worker accused the men of wiretapping their colleagues, hacking foreign governments and stealing trade secrets. It wasn’t true, but the allegations still follow them.

node.title: As U.K. Beckons Truck Drivers, Many in Poland Say ‘No Thanks’
node.description: A special visa offer, aimed at forestalling a supply chain fiasco during the holidays, goes begging for takers.

node.title: Israel to ban entry of foreigners from all countries over Omicron
node.description: Israel is the the first country to shut its borders completely as most major countries impose restrictions on travel from southern Africa, to try to contain the new Covid-19 variant called Omicron.

node.title: Which areas will the traffic light system apply to?
node.description: The government will soon decide what controls will apply in what areas under the new traffic light system, but it is still unclear if they will be applied to DHB boundaries, regions or territories.

node.title: 'It's devastating': Tearful Cairns mother learns she'll be sent to the Gold Coast after COVID hotel fire
node.description: Dozens of people evacuated after a hotel quarantine fire in Cairns say they've been told they'll be flown thousands of kilometres away to complete the rest of their isolation.

node.title: China study warns of 'colossal' COVID outbreak if it opens up, with daily cases forecast to exceed 630,000
node.description: A study by Peking University mathematicians shows China could not afford to lift travel restrictions without more efficient vaccinations or specific treatments.

node.title: Australia to introduce new laws to force media platforms to unmask online trolls
node.description: Australia will introduce legislation to make social media giants provide details of users who post defamatory comments, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said today.

node.title: 'Where are they going to put these families?' - Rest home plans worry residents
node.description: A group of elderly people in Porirua who thought they'd found a home to spend the rest of their lives in could be kicked out.

node.title: Travellers test positive to Omicron COVID-19 strain after arriving in Sydney from southern Africa
node.description: NSW Health confirms two returned travellers have tested positive for the new Omicron COVID-19 variant in Sydney.

node.title: Covid-19: 144 new community cases in NZ today, one further death
node.description: There have been 144 new community cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, with one further death also reported.

node.title: Poor rating result of failure to fill mental health liaison role, DHB says
node.description: The MidCentral District Health Board has been unable to fill a critical role despite advertising nationally and internationally, it says.

node.title: NT records three more local COVID cases linked to Katherine cluster, as remote community enters lockdown
node.description: Three more local COVID-19 cases are recorded in the NT overnight, as the remote community of Lajamanu enters lockdown and testing continues of a South African traveller who may be carrying the new Omicron variant.
